title: 110_hr2399
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007". The Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007 acknowledges that alien smuggling is a transnational crime that threatens US borders, sovereignty, and security. It emphasizes the need for aggressive enforcement efforts and recognizes the law enforcement agencies involved in combating this threat. The Act highlights the importance of providing statutory tools to address this security issue effectively. Existing penalties for alien smuggling are insufficient to provide appropriate punishment for alien smugglers. Current laws often fail to reach the conduct of alien smugglers, transporters, recruiters, guides, and boat captains. Laws concerning failure to heave to are inadequate to punish boat operators and crew engaging in reckless transportation of aliens on the high seas. Alien smuggling rings operate outside the US, requiring extraterritorial jurisdiction for justice. Smuggling can involve dangerous conditions risking injury or death. The Department of Homeland Security will check alien smugglers and smuggled individuals against terrorist watchlists at US borders. Additionally, there will be stronger prosecution and punishment for alien smugglers. Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, including bringing, recruiting, transporting, and harboring them in the United States. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens in the United States. This includes bringing, recruiting, transporting, and harboring them. Those who bring individuals to the US without authorization or harbor them unlawfully will be punished accordingly. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens in the United States. Violators will face fines, imprisonment, or both, depending on the specific offense committed. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling offenses involving unlawful and terrorist aliens in the United States. Offenders face fines, imprisonment, or both, with varying penalties based on the severity of the offense, including fines under title 18, United States Code, and imprisonment ranging from 3 to 20 years. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling offenses involving unlawful and terrorist aliens in the United States. Offenders face fines, imprisonment, or both, with penalties based on the severity of the offense, including fines under title 18, United States Code, and imprisonment ranging from 3 to 30 years for offenses involving terrorist activity or specific violent acts. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address extraterritorial jurisdiction over aggravated sexual abuse and offenses on the high seas. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment, or both, with specific conditions for raising a defense based on necessity. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address extraterritorial jurisdiction over aggravated sexual abuse and offenses on the high seas. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment, or both, with specific conditions for raising a defense based on necessity, including reporting to the Coast Guard and not facilitating illegal entry of aliens unless in exigent circumstances. Religious organizations can also have a defense for certain violations. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow religious denominations to encourage aliens present in the United States to work as ministers or missionaries as volunteers, without compensation as employees, provided they have been members of the denomination for at least one year. The term 'United States' includes various territories, and 'lawful authority' refers to expressly provided permission, authorization, or waiver. The term 'lawful authority' in the Immigration and Nationality Act refers to permission, authorization, or waiver expressly provided for in US immigration laws, excluding any authority obtained fraudulently or not approved. SEC. 5. MARITIME LAW ENFORCEMENT. Penalties for violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. For specific offenses related to alien smuggling, trafficking, or serious bodily injury, penalties can increase to up to 15 years imprisonment. The penalties for violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code can include fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. A limitation on the necessity defense is also outlined, stating that no defense based on necessity can be raised unless the defendant delivers the person to emergency personnel upon reaching shore. The necessity defense outlined in section 2237 of title 18, United States Code limits its application unless the defendant delivers the person to emergency personnel upon reaching shore, reports to the Coast Guard, and does not facilitate illegal entry of aliens into the US. The definition in section 2237(e) of title 18, United States Code is also amended. The definition of 'transportation under inhumane conditions' in section 2237(e) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include various forms of mistreatment during transportation, such as overcrowding or excessive speed. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO THE SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses and obstruction of boarding. Enhancements may be considered for offenses involving flagrant violations, commercial organizations, large groups of transported aliens, endangerment of lives, and facilitation of terrorist activity. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses and obstruction of boarding, considering enhancements for flagrant violations, commercial organizations, large groups of transported aliens, endangerment of lives, and facilitation of terrorist activity. Expedited procedures may be used for promulgating guidelines or amendments. The Sentencing Act of 1987 will be applied under section 21(a) as if the authority had not expired.
